0.text: Studies show that people who practice "cognitive reappraisal" – that is, try to see the situation in a more positive light – experience less stress and irritation in similar situations.
0.fact: Psychologists recommend taking a deep breath and thinking about the long-term consequences in such situations. This helps reduce stress levels and make more rational decisions.

1.text: Studies show that unexpected financial expenses are one of the strongest triggers of stress and irritation for most people.
1.fact: There is a phenomenon called the "price anchor", where people form expectations about the cost of a service based on previous experience or incomplete information. This often leads to disappointment when faced with real prices.

2.text: The practice of mindfulness can help cope with the feeling of injustice. Studies show that people who practice meditation handle such situations more easily.
2.fact: In Japanese culture, there is a concept called "wa" (harmony), which encourages people to avoid confrontation and remain calm even in unfair situations to maintain social harmony.

3.text: Psychologists note that the feeling of helplessness in such situations can quickly lead to irritation. However, active steps to solve the problem promote the release of endorphins, which improve mood.

4.text: Psychologists call ignoring "social death". Research shows that the brain reacts to social exclusion in the same way as it does to physical pain.

5.text: Psychologists call this phenomenon the "illusion of superiority" or the "Dunning-Kruger effect". People with low competence in a particular area often overestimate their abilities.

6.text: The practice of mindfulness can help restore calm more quickly in such situations. Studies show that regular meditation improves control over emotional reactions.

7.text: Psychologists note that our reaction to such situations is often related to "territorial behavior" - the instinctive desire to protect our property and space.
7.fact: Anger management experts recommend using the "STOP" technique (Stop, Take a breath, Observe, Proceed) in such situations to control emotions.

8.text: Psychologists call this phenomenon "reactive resistance". The more pressure we feel, the more we strive to resist, even if the offer might be beneficial.
8.fact: According to a study conducted in the USA, about 68% of shoppers leave a store due to pushy behavior from salespeople.

9.text: In some cultures, such as in Latin America, canceling plans at the last minute is considered less serious than in Northern Europe or North America, reflecting differences in the perception of time and commitments.
9.fact: Studies show that with the development of technology and social networks, people are canceling plans at the last minute more frequently because it has become technically easier to do so.

10.text: Psychologists note that teasing can be perceived by the brain as a form of social threat, activating the same areas as in physical danger.
10.fact: Conflict management experts recommend using the technique of "disarming phrases" - calm responses that reduce tension and deprive the teaser of the desired reaction.

11.text: Psychologists call such behavior "road rage". Studies show that about 80% of drivers experience strong anger while driving at least once a year.
11.fact: The "fundamental attribution error" makes us explain the behavior of others by their personality traits, while attributing our own behavior to external circumstances. This can intensify the negative perception of aggressive drivers.

12.text: Research shows that people often behave more aggressively in anonymous situations, such as driving, where they feel protected by their vehicle.

13.text: A study conducted in a corporate environment showed that about 4% of employees regularly shift the blame for their mistakes onto colleagues.

14.text: Psychologists call the heightened sensitivity to repetitive sounds or movements "misophonia". This condition can cause intense irritation and even anger in some people.
14.fact: Albert Einstein often worked in noisy cafes, claiming that background noise helped him concentrate. This shows how differently people react to external stimuli.

15.text: Psychologists call this phenomenon a "violation of reciprocity". It can cause a strong sense of injustice as it breaks the basic social rule of mutual exchange.

16.text: The "negativity effect" shows that negative events have a stronger impact on our psychological state than positive ones. This explains why a bad day can feel especially difficult.

17.text: The context of a conversation plays a major role in the perception of jokes. If the topic is serious and emotionally significant, jokes can cause greater irritation as they are perceived as disrespectful to the issue.

18.text: The ability to show empathy can help reduce irritation in a dispute. Understanding that a person may not realize their incompetence or have limited knowledge on the topic can change your attitude and reaction.

19.text: According to a study conducted by Harvard University, 70% of participants admitted that third-party intervention in their disputes often leads to an escalation of conflict.

20.text: When we are in a hurry, we often feel a sense of urgency that can intensify irritation. This state is associated with the release of adrenaline, which accelerates the heartbeat and increases stress levels.
20.fact: In psychology, there is a concept of "blocking" when something or someone hinders our intentions or movements. This causes frustration, especially in situations where we feel time pressure.

21.text: Stepping on gum often causes a feeling of disgust, which is one of the basic human emotions. This natural reaction to potentially harmful or unpleasant substances is evolutionarily built into us to protect our health.
21.fact: According to a survey conducted by the British research agency YouGov, about 70% of people feel irritation or disgust when they step on gum.

22.text: Knowing that you are being watched and discussed can intensify feelings of anxiety and stress. This phenomenon is associated with the "observer effect", where a person changes their behavior knowing they are being observed.
22.fact: Princess Diana was often the target of gossip and discussions. She learned to ignore most of the negative attention and focused on her charitable work, which helped her maintain inner peace and confidence.

23.text: Such small mishaps can greatly affect our mood. This is because unexpected negative events disrupt our sense of control and predictability, causing stress and irritation.
23.fact: The "Broken Window Effect": This effect describes how small annoyances can accumulate and intensify negative perception. If you are already in a hurry and under stress, torn pants can become the "last straw" that intensifies your irritation.

24.text: When this happens, it can trigger a feeling of loss of control, which intensifies stress and irritation. People are used to trusting technology, and when it fails, it disrupts our sense of security and predictability.

normal.text: Your level of irritability is extremely low. You remain calm in life situations and do not lose your composure.
normal.title: Normal state

light.text: Sometimes you experience mild irritation, but it does not interfere with your normal lifestyle. You are calmer than most people.
light.title: Mild irritability

severe.text: Sometimes you may lose your composure, many things irritate you. Your level of irritability is about the same as that of most people living in a metropolis.
severe.title: Moderate Irritability

hard.text: You regularly find yourself in a state of irritation. Any little things can set you off. You should pay attention to your mental state.
hard.title: Strong Irritability

extreme.text: Irritability haunts you throughout the day. This is likely leading you to nervous exhaustion, digestive problems, and headaches. You are at risk of developing anxiety disorders. You should consider seeing a psychotherapist.
extreme.title: Extreme Irritability

text: Have you ever considered how often and easily you experience irritation? How does it affect your life, relationships, and well-being? The Novaco Anger Scale test, adapted with a focus on irritability, offers a unique opportunity to delve deeply into understanding your emotional state.

This test, developed in the 1970s by Raymond Novaco, now serves as a tool that helps assess not only the intensity of your irritation but also how it manifests in your daily life. You will learn about the situations that cause you irritation, how you react to them, and what physiological and cognitive reactions accompany these emotions.
